title: Electric potential from a ring of charge

content.question: The figure shows a charged ring of radius <math alttext="0.40 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.40</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The ring has a linear charge density of <math alttext="lambda equals positive 1.0 microcoulomb per meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mfrac><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. The <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is along the central axis of the ring. The electric potential at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at the position <math alttext="x equals negative 0.20 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.20</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is most nearly

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
